Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Pathways of soil N<sub>2</sub>O uptake, consumption, and its driving factors: a review.

AbstractText: Nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O) is an important greenhouse gas that plays a significant role in atmospheric photochemical reactions and contributes to stratospheric ozone depletion. Soils are the main sources of N<sub>2</sub>O emissions. In recent years, it has been demonstrated that soil is not only a source but also a sink of N<sub>2</sub>O uptake and consumption. N<sub>2</sub>O emissions at the soil surface are the result of gross N<sub>2</sub>O production, uptake, and consumption, which are co-occurring processes. Soil N<sub>2</sub>O uptake and consumption are complex biological processes, and their mechanisms are still worth an in-depth systematic study. This paper aimed to systematically address the current research progress on soil N<sub>2</sub>O uptake and consumption. Based on a bibliometric perspective, this study has highlighted the pathways of soil N<sub>2</sub>O uptake and consumption and their driving factors and measurement techniques. This systematic review of N<sub>2</sub>O uptake and consumption will help to further understand N transformations and soil N<sub>2</sub>O emissions.
